intro: Petrosimonia sibirica, commonly known as Siberian rockweed, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the cold climates of Siberia and Central Asia. It belongs to the family Geraniaceae and is characterized by its compact rosette of fleshy, oval-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, whitish bloom. The plant produces small, pinkish to reddish flowers during the summer months, which are clustered in dense inflorescences. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to harsh, arctic or alpine environments. Due to its hardy nature, it is sometimes cultivated in rock gardens or as an ornamental plant in cooler regions.
